facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 19, 1962, of the Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Criminal Revision No. 337-D of 1962

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 19, 1962, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Criminal Revision No. 337-D of 1962.

facts.text: Eight persons were tried by the Assistant Sessions Judge, Delhi, for offences under s. 148, S. 333/149, and s. 332/149, Indian Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: Eight persons were tried by the Assistant Sessions Judge, Delhi, for offences under s. 148, S. 333/149, and s. 332/149, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Assistant Sessions Judge acquitted five of them but convicted the three appellants of all three offences

anchor.surface_text: He acquitted five of them but companyvicted the three appellants before us of all the three offences and sentenced them to undergo rigorous imprisonment for one year

facts.text: Assistant Sessions Judge sentenced appellants to rigorous imprisonment for one year under s. 148, two years under s. 332/149, three years under s. 333/149, all concurrent

anchor.surface_text: and sentenced them to undergo rigorous imprisonment for one year in respect of the offence under S. 148, rigorous imprisonment for two years in respect of the offence under S. 332/149, rigorous imprisonment for three years for the offence under S. 333/149 and ordered that all the sentences will run companycurrently.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge set aside convictions and sentences for s. 148 and s. 333/149, altered conviction to s. 322 simpliciter with same sentence as under s. 332/149

anchor.surface_text: In appeal the Additional Sessions Judge, Delhi, set aside the companyvictions and sentences passed on the appellants for offences under S. 148 and S. 333/149, altered the companyviction of each of the appellants from one under S. 332/149 to S. 322 simpliciter and awarded the same sentence in respect of it as had been awarded by the Assistant Sessions Judge in respect of the offence under s. 332/149.

facts.text: On September 16, 1961, Mukhtiar Singh, Licensing Inspector of the Delhi Municipal Corporation organised a raiding party for catching stray cattle

anchor.surface_text: Briefly stated the prosecution case was that on September 16, 1961, Mukhtiar Singh, Licensing Inspector of the Delhi Municipal Corporation organised a raiding party for catching stray cattle within the limits of the Corporation.

facts.text: Raiding party consisted of Balbir Singh Enforcement Inspector, H. Bhanot Sanitary Inspector, Kishan Singh Head Constable, three foot constables and five cattle-catchers

anchor.surface_text: The party companysisted of Balbir Singh, Enforcement Inspector, H. Bhanot, Sanitary Inspector, Kishan Singh, Head Constable, three foot companystables and five cattle-catchers.

facts.text: Raiding party reached neighbourhood of Mori Gate Chowk at about 5 a.m. and rounded up about 25 or 30 stray cattle consisting of buffaloes and cows

anchor.surface_text: The party reached the neigbourhood of Mori Gate Chowk at about 5 a.m. and rounded up about 25 ,or 30 stray cattle companysisting of buffaloes and companys.

facts.text: Party was taking cattle to Nigambodh Ghat cattle pound via Nicholson Road

anchor.surface_text: While they were taking them to the Nigambodh Ghat cattle pound via Nicholson Road,

facts.text: Three appellants carrying lathis approached the party and threatened them to release cattle or face serious consequences

anchor.surface_text: the three appellants who were carrying lathis with them approached the party and threatened them that unless they released the cattle they would have to face serious companysequences.

facts.text: Members of raiding party informed appellants who they were and cattle-catchers showed identity cards

anchor.surface_text: The members of the party informed them who they were and the cattle-catcbers showed them their identity cards.

facts.text: Appellants raised shouts asking friends to come with lathis to get cattle released by force, other accused arrived and all assaulted party members, caused injuries, released cattle

anchor.surface_text: This, however, only enraged the appellants who raised shouts asking their friends to companye along with lathis in order to help them to get the cattle released by force. Upon hearing the shouts the other accused persons arrived at the spot with lathis, joined the appellants and all of them assaulted the members of the party, caused injuries to them and got the cattle released by force.

facts.text: Kishan Singh (PW2) sustained a grievous injury and some simple injuries

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the assault, W. 2 Kishan Singh sustained a grievous injury as well as some simple injuries,

facts.text: PW 14 Khem, PW 20 Padam Singh, PW 10 Iqbal Singh, PW 19 Nil Bahadur, PW 12 Ram Mehar sustained simple injuries

anchor.surface_text: P.W. 14 Khem, P.W. 20 Padam Singh, W. 10 Iqbal Singh, P.W. 19 Nil Bahadur, P.W. 12 Ram Mehar sustained simple injuries.

facts.text: Incident seen by a number of persons who came to the spot

anchor.surface_text: The incident was seen by a number of persons who happened to companye to the spot at that time.

facts.text: Report lodged with police, investigation taken up, appellants and other accused placed before First Class Magistrate who committed them for trial by Court of Sessions after preliminary enquiry

anchor.surface_text: Eventually a report was lodged with the police, investigation was taken up and the appellants and the other accused were placed before a First Class Magistrate, who, after making a preliminary enquiry, companymitted them for trial by the Court of Sessions.

facts.text: Appellants' defence: bringing cattle after grazing and watering, approached Mori Gate at about 4.30 a.m., group employed by Corporation belaboured them and took them in van to police station

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the appellants was that they were bringing the cattle after grazing and watering them and that when they approached Mori Gate at about 4.30 a.m. a group of persons under the employment of the Corporation met them, belaboured them and eventually took them in a van to the police station.

facts.text: Appellants claimed they acted in exercise of right of private defence of their property

anchor.surface_text: The appellants further say that they had acted in the exercise of their right of private defence of their property. Their defence has been rejected by the companyrts below.

facts.text: Courts below rejected appellants' defence

anchor.surface_text: Their defence has been rejected by the companyrts below.

facts.text: Rounding up operation took half an hour and appellants appeared after cattle were rounded up and being taken to pound

anchor.surface_text: But this companytention is companytrary to the finding of each of the companyrts below which is to the effect that the rounding up operation took half an hour and that it was after the cattle were rounded up and were being taken to the cattle pound that the appellants appeared on the scene.

facts.text: Commissioner delegated power under s.418(1) DMC Act to Licensing Inspectors for seizure of stray cattle

anchor.surface_text: That order runs thus In exercise of the powers companyferred on me by section 491 of the Delhi Municipal Corporation Act, 1957, 1 hereby direct that the power companyferred on me under section 418 1  of the said Act shall subject to my supervision, companytrol and revision be exercised also by the Municipal employees mentioned in companyumn 3 of the schedule given below to the extent stated in companyumn 4 of the schedule. ... 418 1  Seizure of certain Licensing Inspectors In respect of animals Licensing Inspectors stray cattle only

facts.text: Supreme Court holds raiding party had authority to seize and impound the cattle under s.418(1) Delhi Municipal Corporation Act 1957

anchor.surface_text: We cannot, therefore, accept the first point raised by Mr. Kohli. Upon the finding that the raiding party was entitled in law to impound the cattle numberquestion of private defence arises.

facts.text: No right of private defence arises as raiding party acted under colour of office

anchor.surface_text: Upon the finding that the raiding party was entitled in law to impound the cattle numberquestion of private defence arises. anchor.surface_text: It will thus be seen that the meaning to be attached to the word abandoned would depend upon the context in which it is used. in the context in which it occurs in S. 418 1 , the meaning which can reasonably be attached to the word abandoned is let loose in the sense of being left unattended and certainly not ownerless.

concepts.interpretation: Meaning of 'abandoned' depends on context in s.418(1).

anchor.surface_text: It is the duty of the court in construing a statute to give effect to the intention of the legislature. If, therefore, giving a literal meaning to a word used by the draftsman, particularly in a penal statute, would defeat the object of the legislature, which is to suppress a mischief, the court can depart from the dictionary meaning or even the popular meaning of the word and instead give it a meaning which will advance the remedy and suppress the mischief.

concepts.interpretation: Court may depart from literal/dictionary meaning in penal statute to suppress mischief and advance remedy.

holdings.text: The raiding party was entitled in law to impound the cattle.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot, therefore, accept the first point raised by Mr. Kohli. Upon the finding that the raiding party was entitled in law to impound the cattle noquestion of private defence arises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valid delegation under s.491 DMC Act to Licensing Inspectors; cattle 'abandoned' as left unattended per contextual and purposive interpretation of s.418(1).

holdings.text: There is no right of private defence against the act of the raiding party.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the finding that the raiding party was entitled in law to impound the cattle noquestion of private defence arises. For, S. 99 of the lndan Penal Code specifically says that there is no right of private defence against an act which does not reasonably cause the apprehension of death or of previous hurt,, if done, or attempted to be done by the direction of a public servant acting in good faith under colour of his office.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.99 IPC: no private defence against public servant acting in good faith under colour of office; raiding party's act fully justifiable.

holdings.text: The delegation order under s.418(1) DMC Act is established and effective even if not on trial record.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the finding that the raiding party was entitled in law to impound the cattle noquestion of private defence arises. For, S. 99 of the lndan Penal Code specifically says that there is no right of private defence against an act which does not reasonably cause the apprehension of death or of previous hurt,, if done, or attempted to be done by the direction of a public servant acting in good faith under colour of his office.

We cannot, therefore, accept the first point raised by Mr. Kohli. Upon the finding that the raiding party was entitled in law to impound the cattle noquestion of private defense arises. For, S. 99 of the lndan Penal Code specifically says that there is no right of private defence against an act which does number reasonably cause the apprehension of death or of previous hurt,, if

But according to Mr. Kohli delegation of this power has not been established in this case. It is true that the Order of the Commissioner delegating the power under s. 418 1  is not on the record of the case. It has, however, been placed before us along with the statement of the case.

We cannot, therefore, accept the first point raised by Mr. Kohli. Upon the finding that the raiding party was entitled in law to impound the cattle noquestion of private defense arises. For, S. 99 of the lndan Penal Code specifically says that there is no right of private defence against an act which does number reasonably cause the apprehension of death or of previous hurt,, if

Mr. Kohli, however, said that the delegation of power is in- effective because, according to him, it purports to make a general delegation of power and does number specify the names of persons to whom the power is delegated. A perusal of the schedule below the order shows that the power of seizure of certain animals is specifically delegated...

We cannot, therefore, accept the first point raised by Mr. Kohli. Upon the finding that the raiding party was entitled in law to impound the cattle noquestion of private defense arises. For, S. 99 of the lndan Penal Code specifically says that there is no right of private defence against an act which does number reasonably cause the apprehension of death or of previous hurt,, if

Then Mr. Kohli says that the words in the order of delegation shall subject to my supervision, companytrol and revision be exercised also by the Municipal employees mentioned in companyumn 3 of the schedule would show that the Commissioners actual presence on the spot was necessary. It is sufficient to say that shall subject to my supervision etc., does number mean under my supervision etc.

We cannot, therefore, accept the first point raised by Mr. Kohli. Upon the finding that the raiding party was entitled in law to impound the cattle noquestion of private defense arises. For, S. 99 of the lndan Penal Code specifically says that there is no right of private defence against an act which does number reasonably cause the apprehension of death or of previous hurt,, if

But this companytention is companytrary to the finding of each of the companyrts below which is to the effect that the rounding up operation took half an hour and that it was after the cattle were rounded up and were being taken to the cattle pound that the appellants appeared on the scene.

We cannot, therefore, accept the first point raised by Mr. Kohli. Upon the finding that the raiding party was entitled in law to impound the cattle noquestion of private defense arises. For, S. 99 of the lndan Penal Code specifically says that there is no right of private defence against an act which does number reasonably cause the apprehension of death or of previous hurt,, if
